programs_offered: DRR Type I (Demand Response Resources - Energy Market)
DRR Type II (Demand Response Resources - Energy + Ancillary Services)
programs_eliminated: EDR (Emergency Demand Response) - Eliminated for 2025/26 planning year per FERC filing April 25, 2025

notification_time_less_than_2hrs_and_dur.description: Full capacity credit for fastest response resources

notification_time_2_to_4hrs.description: Reduced capacity credit for moderate response time

notification_time_4_to_6hrs.description: Reduced capacity credit for slower response time

energy_market_payments.drrTypeI: Economic dispatch payments at locational marginal prices (LMP)
energy_market_payments.drrTypeII: Energy plus ancillary services payments including regulation reserves, spinning reserves, supplemental reserves, and ramp products

eligibility.locational_information_requirement: Elemental Pricing Nodes (EPNodes) required starting 2025/26 (replaced Zip Codes)
eligibility.metering_requirements: Interval metering required for most methodologies; statistical sampling allowed for Baseline Type-II aggregated resources without interval meters

methodologies_available: Firm Service Level - Performance based on ability to reduce to specified demand level regardless of consumption
Meter Before/Meter After - Electricity consumption measured over prescribed time period
Baseline Type-II - Statistical sampling for aggregated resources without interval metering
baseline_methodology.documentation_reference: MISO Business Practices Manual BPM-026-r9 (effective October 1, 2022)

battery_suitability.rating_rationale: Highly suitable for BESS participation with multiple pathways and strong capacity prices

capacity_market_suitability.notes: Excellent capacity prices in 2025/26 planning year ($666.50/MW-day summer, $217/MW-day annualized). Low 0.1 MW minimum allows smaller BESS. Fast response time (<2hrs) and >4hr duration capability earns 100% capacity credit - ideal for BESS capabilities.

energy_market_suitability.notes: DRR Type I allows economic dispatch at LMP. BESS can participate as behind-the-meter non-injecting storage under demand response rules, or as Electric Storage Resource (ESR) for full energy market participation.

ancillary_services_suitability.notes: DRR Type II provides access to regulation reserves, spinning reserves, supplemental reserves, and ramp products - all excellent revenue streams for BESS with fast response characteristics.

battery_suitability.participation_pathway_recommendation: Behind-the-meter BESS can participate as Demand Response (simpler registration). Front-of-meter or larger BESS should register as Electric Storage Resource (ESR) for full market access including energy and ancillary services.
barriers_and_considerations: ESR requires transmission service when charging (NITS or PTP)
Must choose between DR participation or ESR participation - cannot do both simultaneously
EDR program eliminated for 2025/26 reduces emergency revenue opportunities
EPNode locational registration required (more precise than zip code)

optimal_bess_specifications.response_time: <2 hours notification time for maximum capacity credit

south_dakota_specific_notes.regional_designation: Part of MISO North/Central subregion for capacity pricing
south_dakota_specific_notes.zone_clarification: South Dakota is not a separate 'Zone 6' - it is part of the broader North/Central pricing region that includes ND, SD, MT, and northern states
south_dakota_specific_notes.capacity_market_tightness: 2025/26 planning year showed significant capacity shortage in North/Central region driving record summer prices ($666.50/MW-day vs $30/MW-day prior year)

edr_elimination.rationale: MISO has never called upon EDRs in its history; eliminating dual registration of LMRs as EDRs

lmr_reforms.status: Under development through RASC-2019-9 stakeholder process

ferc_order_2222_implementation.scope: Distributed Energy Resource (DER) aggregation participation in wholesale markets

data_sources.source: Enel North America - MISO 2025 Capacity Auction Results
RTO Insider - MISO Summer Capacity Prices 2025/26
PCI Energy Solutions - DR LMR in MISO Market

research_notes: MISO demand response programs offer excellent opportunities for BESS in South Dakota. The 2025/26 capacity auction showed dramatic price increases (22x increase from prior year) driven by capacity shortages in the North/Central region. Key findings: (1) South Dakota is part of MISO North/Central pricing region, not a separate 'Zone 6'; (2) Capacity prices are exceptional at $666.50/MW-day for summer 2025 and $217/MW-day annualized; (3) BESS can participate either as behind-the-meter demand response (simpler) or as Electric Storage Resource (full market access); (4) 0.1 MW minimum allows smaller BESS projects; (5) Fast response time (<2hrs) and >4hr duration earns 100% capacity credit - ideal for BESS; (6) DRR Type II provides access to lucrative ancillary services markets; (7) EDR program eliminated for 2025/26 but LMR and DRR programs remain strong; (8) Market participant certification required (60-90 day timeline); (9) EPNode locational registration now required. The combination of high capacity prices, low barriers to entry, and multiple revenue streams makes this an excellent opportunity for BESS projects in South Dakota.
quality_score_explanation: High quality research with verified capacity clearing prices from official MISO auction results, detailed program parameters from MISO Business Practices Manual and workshop presentations, and recent regulatory filings. Score limited to 8 (not 10) because: (1) Could not access some PDFs directly to verify exact details; (2) Some operational parameters like annual event limits not publicly available; (3) Baseline methodology details referenced but not fully extracted from BPM-026; (4) South Dakota-specific transmission or zonal constraints not documented. All capacity prices and program structures are from official MISO sources and industry analysis.
